text:
hello folks! I've got a python problem with the lab from yesterday.

when I try to create the 'sentiment' column, it says:
```The `text` argument passed to `__init__(text)` must be a string, not <class 'float'>


I checked the type of the 'review text' column with a for loop and some of them are foats. I'm trying to change them without success. could you help me?```

elements.text:
hello folks! I've got a python problem with the lab from yesterday.

when I try to create the 'sentiment' column, it says:

The `text` argument passed to `__init__(text)` must be a string, not <class 'float'>


I checked the type of the 'review text' column with a for loop and some of them are foats. I'm trying to change them without success. could you help me?

text: Try to use .apply(lambda) for that. It should go through the column in this case. Had the same issue yesterday.

text:
I finally did that:
clothing_df = clothing_df.dropna(subset=['review text'])

and that to check if it's ok:
num_float = 0
for i in clothing_df['review text']:
    if type(i) == float:
        num_float += 1

print(num_float)

before doing
*clothingdf[‘sentiment’]=clothingdf[‘Review Text’].apply(lambda x: TextBlob(x).sentiment.polarity)*

text:
`df.isna().sum()` is always good to check all NaNs. No need to write a for-loop.
or in your case
`clothing_df['review text'].isna().sum()`

elements.text: df.isna().sum()

is always good to check all NaNs. No need to write a for-loop.
or in your case
clothing_df['review text'].isna().sum()

text:
Hey would there be a good way to order bars within a subgroup of a catplot? I tried to add the order statement below, but once I do that all bars disappear..

```sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")


g = sns.catplot(
    data = avg_sentiment, kind="bar",
    x = "sentiment", y = "division-name", hue = "department-name",
    ci="sd", palette="dark", alpha=.6, height=6, orient = "h",
    order = min_sentiment.sort_values('sentiment', ascending = False)
)
g.despine(left=True)
g.set_axis_labels("Avg Sentiment Polarity")
g.set(title = 'Avg Sentiment by Departments');```

elements.text: Hey would there be a good way to order bars within a subgroup of a catplot? I tried to add the order statement below, but once I do that all bars disappear..

sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")


g = sns.catplot(
    data = avg_sentiment, kind="bar",
    x = "sentiment", y = "division-name", hue = "department-name",
    ci="sd", palette="dark", alpha=.6, height=6, orient = "h",
    order = min_sentiment.sort_values('sentiment', ascending = False)
)
g.despine(left=True)
g.set_axis_labels("Avg Sentiment Polarity")
g.set(title = 'Avg Sentiment by Departments');

text:
I think the order might be only for one column, but to achieve the view you want, you could reindex- have you tried creating the order you want in a groupby() ? something like :
*reviews.groupby([‘division name’]).apply(lambda x: (<http://x.gr|x.gr>oupby(‘department’).mean().sort_values(‘sentiment’,ascending=False))*

elements.text: I think the order might be only for one column, but to achieve the view you want, you could reindex- have you tried creating the order you want in a groupby() ? something like :
reviews.groupby([‘division name’]).apply(lambda x: (
x.gr
oupby(‘department’).mean().sort_values(‘sentiment’,ascending=False))

text: you can set the index on your results table if you create a grouped version of the dataframe … index can be set on multiple columns. then try plotting. but youre right, i think there should be a solution to sort nested in seaborn- i just dont know it

text: <https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.set_index.html>

or a simpler hack…. looks like you can set the barplot in a specific order - this might work
`sns.barplot(x *=*` `'class', y *=*` `'fare', data *=*` `df,`
            `order *=*` `["Third", "Second", "First"])`

elements.text: or a simpler hack…. looks like you can set the barplot in a specific order - this might work
sns.barplot(x
'class', y
'fare', data
df,
order
["Third", "Second", "First"])
